@riggio_l @PeterSchiff Peter and I agree on many of the problems.

16/16 There are many people hurting in the world right now. Even more will get hurt if we don't respond with stimulus quickly & decisively.

The stimulus implementation is really important. 

Any slip in execution could put us in previously unthinkable place. Be kind to others🙏🏽

15/ There are many people much smarter than me who have (a) taught me about these concepts, (b) been incredibly kind with sharing their thought process publicly, and (c) are no-brainer follows if you want to learn more.\n\n@RaoulGMI and @DTAPCAP are the two that I'll mention here.

14/ The United States has been the leader of the free world for a long time.

That doesn't make us immune to mistakes or missteps.

We have seen other countries weaken their currency to the point of hyperinflation (Zimbabwe, Venezuela, etc). 

We have to be careful right now.

13/ The world operated on sound money for thousands of years. 

We have only operated on fiat currencies for about 50 years.

Fiat currency drives an addiction to stimulus, which is the devaluation of a currency.

We have seen how that ends throughout history.

12/ I don't share these thoughts to suggest that (a) the US dollar will fail or (b) to try to predict timing of any events in the thread.

Instead, I'm surprised that no investor has suggested we could be seeing the failure of fiat experiment.

I'm looking for feedback/critiques

11/ If we see the US flood the market with dollars to weaken the dollar, it wouldn't surprise me to see someone take a run at a massive short against the dollar too.

Soros broke the pound on Black Wednesday.

If we see high inflation, the incentive is too big for no one to try.

10/ The fiat currency experiment is most vulnerable to failure when an economy gets addicted to monetary stimulus.

That stimulus is merely the long term devaluation of a currency. You can't devalue a currency forever.

The US economy is a stimulus addict today.

9/ The most dangerous outcome is that we see the failure of the fiat currency experiment.

We are only 49 years into this experiment. There is no guarantee that it will survive.

While probably less than a 5% chance it happens today, it is definitely a non-zero possibility.

8/ When the US goes to weaken the dollar, this means that it will take more dollars to buy the same amount of equities, commodities, etc.

Almost every asset price should rise, but the inflation hedges are likely to rise the most (gold, Bitcoin, etc).

Example: gold in 2009-2011.

7/ The transition from the current deflationary environment to an inflationary one brings two possible scenarios that people should watch for:

a) Asset prices exploding
b) Potential failure of fiat system

Keep reading to understand both.

6/ When the US floods the market with dollars, they are essentially devaluing the dollar. \n\nThe current environment is a deflationary one (dollars get more valuable), but once they make a move we will move to an inflationary environment (dollars get less valuable).

5/ The United States is going to have to weaken the dollar at some point. This is only way to stop the bleeding.

They will have to flood the market with trillions of US dollars in order to accomplish this. 

My guess is that it will require at least $5 trillion.

3/ Another way to think of a liquidity crisis is that the dollar is strengthening against every other asset (equities, commodities, etc).\n\nThis means that dollars are more valuable. It takes less of them to buy the same asset.

2/ In a modern day liquidity crisis, investors will sell any asset that has a liquid market so that they can gain access to US dollars.

This is why you are seeing every asset sell off. You see it in equities, gold, Treasuries, Bitcoin, etc.

No asset is immune.

12/12 

Ultimately, investing is a game of psychology and discipline.

The next market downturn will teach everyone the same lessons as every market downturn before it:

Time and compound growth are your greatest allies.

11/ To make all of this worse, baby boomers who got crushed the hardest during the GFC are also many of same ones who became most aggressive in their risk appetite over the last few years.

They were trying to make up for lost time. 

Another GFC could be game over financially.

10/ The baby boomer generation is likely to learn a really, really hard truth — many of them can't retire.

The timing of two financial crisis within the last 15 years of your working life is a cocktail for disaster.

Some were prepared, but most weren't / aren't.

9/ But what makes the prospects of another financial crisis especially bad for baby boomers over other generations is that the baby boomers don't have time on their side.\n\nThey are all reaching retirement age. They should be preparing to stop working and enjoying their wealth.

8/ Now imagine what will happen if baby boomers are net long to public equities with a majority of their wealth and the economy runs into a brick wall.

The same generation that got hammered in the GFC will get hammered again. 

Two crisis in under 15 years. Not good.

7/ If we are headed into another global recession, many baby boomers are going to realize they were saving when they should have been investing and started investing when they should have been worried about saving. \n\nThe psychology of investing will screw anyone up.

6/ Over the last 12-24 months, it seems like every stock and asset someone could buy kept going up in value.

Every investor was a genius. They couldn't lose.

So right when the baby boomer generation should be worried about saving, they started to invest very heavily again.

5/ Over the last few years, baby boomers started to gain back their confidence and began to invest in the stock market and other financial markets again. \n\nThey were able to capture some of the upside from the decade-long bull market, but not nearly enough of it.

4/ This switch from investing to saving mentality came at the worst time — we started the longest bull market in history coming out of the Global Financial Crisis.\n\nThe baby boomers were saving when they should have been investing.

3/ The baby boomer generation was not only set back financially, but they also had their confidence shaken.\n\nThey quite literally left financial markets in many cases and became more concerned about saving, rather than investing.

2/ An entire generation had grown up believing two things — the American financial system was bulletproof and their greatest asset was the home they owned.\n\nThe Global Financial Crisis shook those two assumptions at the core.

1/ Most people are aware of the carnage that was created by the Great Financial Crisis. It took peoples' homes, savings, and set them back years in their financial journey.\n\nIt also changed the way that many baby boomers interacted with money.
0/ One of the things that very few people are talking about is how unprepared the baby boomer generation is for an economic downturn.\n\nTime for a thread 👇🏽👇🏽

This is a really big deal.

Just a small peek into the future of finance.
